case_name: Wijesinghe v. Attorney General and Others
cause_of_action: Fundamental Rights - Equal Protection
subject_matter: Violation of equal protection and non-discrimination guarantees in termination of service
key_facts: Petitioner, a Sub Postmistress, was terminated without charge and without hearing. Claimed violation of Articles 12(1), 12(2) and 126 of Constitution regarding equal protection and non-discrimination.
statute_ordinance_applied: Constitution of Sri Lanka - Article 12 (Equal Protection)
Common Law - Master and Servant relationship
court_finding: Held that dismissal at common law by master is valid without hearing. However, to claim constitutional violation, petitioner must show discriminatory treatment contrary to Article 12(2). Mere wrongful decision or breach of law does not constitute fundamental rights violation.
legal_principles: Distinction between ordinary rights and fundamental rights
Burden of proof on petitioner to establish discrimination
remedy_granted: Application dismissed - No breach of fundamental rights established
citation_format: [1979] SC NO. 13 - Wijesinghe v. Attorney General
significance: Landmark case establishing distinction between ordinary legal rights and fundamental constitutional rights

case_name: Ratnayake v. Attorney-General
cause_of_action: Fundamental Rights - Equal Protection and Discrimination
subject_matter: Alleged discriminatory transfer from teaching position
key_facts: Petitioner, a teacher, challenged transfer to another school claiming violation of Article 12(1). Petitioner completed postgraduate diploma and alleged transfer was retaliatory for pursuing education.
statute_ordinance_applied: Constitution of Sri Lanka - Article 12 (Equal Protection)
Public Service Regulations - Transfer of transferable officers
court_finding: Burden is on petitioner to prove discriminatory treatment. Not sufficient to show transfer was wrongful - must establish unequal treatment compared to similarly situated persons. Petitioner failed to prove discriminatory intent or treatment.
legal_principles: Burden of proof in Article 12 cases
Requirement to show comparative treatment of similarly situated persons
Difference between wrongful act and discrimination
Discretionary government actions subject to Article 12 scrutiny
remedy_granted: Application rejected - Petitioner failed to establish discrimination
citation_format: [1997] 2 SLR - Ratnayake v. Attorney-General (SC FR NO. 236/96)
significance: Clarifies high burden of proof required in discrimination cases under Article 12(1)

case_name: Sunila Abeysekera v. Ariya Rubasinghe and Others
cause_of_action: Fundamental Rights - Freedom of Speech and Expression
subject_matter: Alleged violation of Article 14(1)(a) freedom of expression through restrictive regulations
key_facts: Chief Editor and Publisher alleged impugned regulations violated Articles 12 and 14(1)(a). Claimed regulations were discriminatory, arbitrary, and prevented formation and communication of public information. Regulations alleged as pretext for suppressing national security criticism.
statute_ordinance_applied: Constitution of Sri Lanka - Article 14 (Freedom of Speech and Expression)
Constitution of Sri Lanka - Article 12 (Equal Protection)
Constitution of Sri Lanka - Article 10 (Freedom of Thought and Conscience)
court_finding: Regulations were framed in reasonably precise terms and confined to defined circumstances. No violation of Article 12(1) established as regulations applied equally to all persons without discriminatory application. Freedom of expression can be restricted on legitimate grounds including national security.
legal_principles: Regulations must be precise and not overbroad
National security as legitimate restriction ground
Requirement to show actual discriminatory application, not mere facial discrimination
remedy_granted: Application dismissed - Regulations upheld as constitutional
citation_format: [2000] 1 SLR - Sunila Abeysekera v. Ariya Rubasinghe
significance: Balances freedom of expression with national security concerns under Article 14

case_name: Lion Brewery (Ceylon) PLC v. Respondents
cause_of_action: Constitutional Rights and Commercial Law
subject_matter: Equal treatment in commercial contract enforcement and constitutional protections
key_facts: Major commercial entity (Lion Brewery) involved in appeals regarding constitutional protections in commercial dispute resolution and equal access to justice.
statute_ordinance_applied: Sale of Goods Ordinance No. 40 of 1896
court_finding: Court examined whether party was entitled to equal protection in contract enforcement and whether constitutional protections apply to commercial disputes.
legal_principles: Application of constitutional protections to private commercial relationships
Equal access to justice in commercial matters
State duty to ensure fair contract enforcement
remedy_granted: Court determined constitutional applicability in commercial context
significance: Recent case addressing intersection of constitutional rights and commercial law

case_name: Constitutional Right to Access Court - Arbour Case
cause_of_action: Fundamental Right to Access Justice
legal_area: Constitutional Law - Article 13 / Access to Justice
subject_matter: Right to bring application before Supreme Court for fundamental rights violations
key_facts: Petitioners challenged restrictions on right to petition Supreme Court for fundamental rights protection. Claimed barriers to access violated Article 126 jurisdiction and constitutional right to remedy.
court_finding: Access to Supreme Court for fundamental rights protection is itself a fundamental right. Restrictions must be justified and proportionate. Court affirmed right to petition for relief.
legal_principles: Article 126 not subject to unreasonable restrictions
Procedural justice and access to remedies
remedy_granted: Right to petition upheld; Restrictions removed or modified
significance: Affirms justiciability of constitutional rights and access to courts

case_name: Case Establishing Standards for Arbitrary Action
cause_of_action: Fundamental Right - Protection from Arbitrary Action
subject_matter: Arbitrary action by state violating Article 12 equal protection guarantee
key_facts: State authority acted arbitrarily in denying rights/benefits. Action had no rational basis and discriminatory effect on particular class of persons.
statute_ordinance_applied: Administrative Law - Principles of Natural Justice
court_finding: Action found to be arbitrary and lacking rational nexus to legitimate state purpose. Arbitrary action inherently violates Article 12 protection.
legal_principles: Test for arbitrariness in state action
remedy_granted: Quashing of arbitrary action; Declaration of rights; Mandatory order
significance: Establishes test and principles for identifying arbitrary action under Article 12

case_name: Fundamental Right Against Arbitrary Detention
cause_of_action: Fundamental Right - Protection from Arbitrary Arrest and Detention
subject_matter: Unlawful arrest and detention without compliance with law
key_facts: Person arrested without warrant. Detained beyond lawful period (24 hours). Not informed of charges. Violated Article 13(1) right against arbitrary arrest.
statute_ordinance_applied: Constitution - Article 13 (Freedom from Arrest and Detention)
court_finding: Arrest without warrant violated Article 13(1) unless justified. Detention beyond 24 hours without judicial authorization constitutes arbitrary detention. Duty to produce before court breached.
remedy_granted: Release of detainee; Damages for unlawful detention; Mandamus for judicial production
significance: Reinforces strict protection against arbitrary arrest and detention under Article 13

case_name: Freedom of Speech and Journalistic Expression
cause_of_action: Fundamental Right - Freedom of Speech and Expression
subject_matter: Restriction on media reporting and journalistic freedom
key_facts: Journalist restricted from publishing reports on matters of public concern. Authority issued prohibition order claiming national security without substantiation.
statute_ordinance_applied: Constitution - Article 14 (Freedom of Speech and Expression)
court_finding: Freedom of press essential in democratic society. Restrictions require compelling justification. Burden on restricting authority to prove necessity and proportionality. Bare claim of national security insufficient.
legal_principles: Press freedom as cornerstone of democracy
remedy_granted: Lifting of publication prohibition; Declaration of journalistic freedom
significance: Protects journalistic freedom and press from unreasonable restrictions

case_name: Freedom of Religion and Conscience
cause_of_action: Fundamental Right - Freedom of Religion and Conscience
subject_matter: Restriction on religious practice and worship
key_facts: Religious organization prohibited from conducting worship or practicing religion. State imposed restrictions on religious freedom claiming public order concerns.
statute_ordinance_applied: Constitution - Article 10 (Freedom of Thought and Conscience)
Constitution - Article 14 (Freedom of Association and Assembly)
International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights
court_finding: Freedom of religion is fundamental and cannot be arbitrarily restricted. State restrictions require strict justification based on real threat, not speculation.
remedy_granted: Declaration of religious freedom; Lifting of restrictions; Damages
significance: Protects religious minorities from discriminatory restrictions

case_name: Property Rights and Constitutional Protection
cause_of_action: Fundamental Right - Protection of Property
subject_matter: Arbitrary deprivation of property without due process
key_facts: Property seized by state without compensation or legal procedure. Owner claims violation of constitutional protection under Article 12 and due process principles.
court_finding: While state may acquire property for public purpose, must follow legal procedures and provide just compensation. Arbitrary seizure violates Article 12 protections.
remedy_granted: Restoration of property or compensation; Damages
significance: Protects property owners from arbitrary state deprivation

case_name: Right to Peaceful Assembly and Protest
cause_of_action: Fundamental Right - Freedom of Peaceful Assembly
subject_matter: Restriction on right to hold public demonstration and peaceful protest
key_facts: Police issued order prohibiting peaceful assembly and protest on matters of public concern. Protesters claimed violation of Article 14(1)(d) right to peaceful assembly.
statute_ordinance_applied: Constitution - Article 14 (Freedom of Association and Assembly)
court_finding: Right to peaceful assembly is protected right. Prior restraint requires compelling justification. Generic concern for public order insufficient. Specific credible threat required.
legal_principles: Right to peaceful assembly for political expression
remedy_granted: Declaration of assembly right; Quashing of prohibition order
significance: Protects democratic right to protest and public assembly

case_name: Gender Equality and Discrimination
cause_of_action: Fundamental Right - Gender-Based Discrimination
subject_matter: Discriminatory law or policy based on gender
key_facts: Law or policy creates distinction between men and women affecting rights/benefits. Petitioner claims violation of Article 12(1) equal protection guarantee.
court_finding: Gender-based classification subject to strict scrutiny. Must serve important governmental objective and be substantially related to achievement of that objective.
remedy_granted: Declaration of invalidity; Damages; Remedial legislation direction
significance: Advances gender equality protection under Constitution

case_name: Caste-Based Discrimination
cause_of_action: Fundamental Right - Protection from Caste Discrimination
subject_matter: Discrimination based on caste violating constitutional equality
key_facts: Petitioner denied access to services, property, or opportunities based on caste status. Claims violation of Article 12(1) equality guarantee.
court_finding: Caste-based discrimination violates constitutional equality. While not explicitly listed, caste falls within 'other grounds' category in Article 12(2). State must protect marginalized groups from discrimination.
remedy_granted: Declaration of right to non-discrimination; Damages; Injunction
significance: Extends constitutional protection to marginalized caste communities

case_name: Right to Education
cause_of_action: Fundamental Right - Access to Education
subject_matter: Denial or restriction of educational access
key_facts: Students denied access to education based on economic status, gender, or disability. Petitioners claim constitutional right to education.
court_finding: While Constitution does not explicitly guarantee right to education as fundamental right, state has duty to facilitate access. Arbitrary denial or discrimination violates Article 12.
remedy_granted: Direction to provide educational access; Damages; Mandamus
significance: Extends constitutional protection to educational access

case_name: Right to Health and Medical Treatment
cause_of_action: Fundamental Right - Access to Healthcare
legal_area: Constitutional Law - Article 14 / Right to Life (Article 13)
subject_matter: Denial or deprivation of essential medical treatment
key_facts: Patient denied access to medical treatment causing health deterioration. Claims violation of right to life and constitutional protection.
statute_ordinance_applied: Constitution - Article 13 (Freedom from Torture and Right to Life)
International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights
court_finding: Right to health derives from right to life in Article 13. State has duty to provide essential medical care. Arbitrary denial may violate fundamental rights.
legal_principles: Health as component of right to life
remedy_granted: Mandamus for medical treatment; Damages; Compensation
significance: Recognizes health rights derived from right to life protection

case_name: Right to Privacy and Personal Data Protection
cause_of_action: Fundamental Right - Privacy
subject_matter: Unlawful surveillance or disclosure of private information
key_facts: Personal information collected, stored, or disclosed without consent. Petitioner claims violation of privacy rights and constitutional protection.
court_finding: Privacy recognized as fundamental right derived from constitutional protections. Unlawful surveillance or disclosure violates Article 14 and Article 12 protections.
remedy_granted: Injunction against surveillance/disclosure; Damages; Data deletion order
significance: Recognizes and protects privacy as fundamental right

case_name: Prohibition of Torture and Cruel Treatment
cause_of_action: Fundamental Right - Prohibition of Torture
subject_matter: Torture, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment in custody
key_facts: Person subjected to torture or cruel treatment in police custody. Petitioner claims absolute violation of Article 13(2) - non-derogable right.
court_finding: Article 13(2) prohibition on torture is absolute and non-derogable. No justification can validate torture. Even national emergency cannot justify torture. Burden on state to disprove torture allegation.
legal_principles: Reversal of burden in torture cases
remedy_granted: Declaration of torture; Substantial damages; Criminal referral; Compensation
significance: Reaffirms absolute prohibition of torture under Constitution

case_name: Right to Fair Labor and Employment
cause_of_action: Fundamental Right - Fair Employment and Labor Rights
subject_matter: Unfair labor practices and workplace discrimination
key_facts: Worker subjected to unfair practices: wage non-payment, hazardous conditions, termination without cause. Claims violations of constitutional protections.
court_finding: While labor rights not explicitly protected as fundamental rights, discriminatory employment practices and hazardous conditions violate Article 12 equality and can breach Article 13 protection.
remedy_granted: Reinstatement or damages; Unpaid wages; Compensation for hazardous exposure
significance: Extends constitutional protection to employment context

case_name: Environmental Protection and Right to Clean Environment
cause_of_action: Fundamental Right - Environmental Protection
subject_matter: Environmental pollution and deprivation of clean environment
key_facts: Industrial pollution causing environmental harm affecting community health and livelihood. Petitioners claim constitutional right to clean environment.
court_finding: While environmental protection not explicit fundamental right, derives from Article 14 protections and state's Article 27 directive. Severe environmental harm affecting health can violate constitutional protections.
remedy_granted: Injunction against pollution; Environmental restoration; Damages; Compensation
significance: Recognizes environmental protection derived from constitutional principles

case_name: Rights of Persons with Disabilities
cause_of_action: Fundamental Right - Non-Discrimination Against Persons with Disabilities
subject_matter: Disability-based discrimination in access to services or opportunities
key_facts: Person with disability denied access to public services, facilities, or employment due to disability status. Claims violation of Article 12 equal protection.
court_finding: Discrimination based on disability violates Article 12. State has duty to ensure reasonable accommodation and equal access. Mere physical barriers can constitute discriminatory conduct.
remedy_granted: Access/accommodation order; Damages; Institutional reform direction
significance: Protects rights of persons with disabilities from discrimination
